title: 107_hr456
content:
The "Tax Relief and Marriage Penalty Elimination Act of 2001" aims to eliminate the marriage penalty in individual income tax rates. SEC. 101 of the "Tax Relief and Marriage Penalty Elimination Act of 2001" eliminates the marriage penalty in individual income tax rates by imposing taxes on married individuals filing joint returns and surviving spouses. The tax rates based on taxable income are as follows:
- Not over $54,100: 15% of taxable income
- Over $54,100 but not over $131,100: $8,115 plus 28% of the excess over $54,100
- Over $131,100 but not over $273,500: $29,675 plus 31% of the excess over $131,100
- Over $273,500 but not over $594,700: $73,819 plus 36% of the excess over $273,500
- Over $594,700: $189,451 plus 39.6% of the excess over $594,700. There is a tax imposed on the taxable income of every head of a household according to a specific table. Tax rates for taxable income for individuals are as follows:
- Not over $43,280: 15% of taxable income
- Over $43,280 but not over $104,880: $6,492 plus 28% of the excess over $43,280
- Over $104,880 but not over $218,800: $23,740 plus 31% of the excess over $104,880
- Over $218,800 but not over $475,760: $59,055.20 plus 36% of the excess over $218,800
- Over $475,760: $151,560.80 plus 39.6% of the excess over $475,760. Tax is imposed on the taxable income of individuals not covered by subsections (a) or (b) according to a specified table. Tax is imposed on the taxable income of individuals not covered by subsections (a) or (b) according to a specified table, with varying tax rates based on income brackets. Tax is imposed on the taxable income of estates and trusts according to a specified table with varying tax rates based on income brackets. Tax is imposed on the taxable income of estates and trusts according to a specified table with varying tax rates based on income brackets. The tax rates range from 15% for income not over $1,800 to 39.6% for income over $8,900, with specific dollar amounts and percentages for each income bracket. Subsection (f) of section 1 is amended to update years from 1993 to 2001 and 1992 to 2000 in various paragraphs. Conforming amendments are made to multiple provisions by changing the year from 1992 to 2000 in each instance. Sections 221(g)(1)(B), 512(d)(2)(B), 513(h)(2)(C)(ii), 685(c)(3)(B), 877(a)(2), 911(b)(2)(D)(ii)(II), 2032A(a)(3)(B), 2503(b)(2)(B), 2631(c)(1)(B), 4001(e)(1)(B), 4261(e)(4)(A)(ii), 6039F(d), 6323(i)(4)(B), 6334(g)(1)(B), 6601(j)(3)(B), and 7430(c)(1) are referenced. Amendment to section 42(h)(6)(G)(i) replaces "1987" with "2000". Sections 468B(b)(1), 511(b)(1), 641(a), and 641(d)(2)(A) are also mentioned. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000, affecting various sections by replacing "section 1(e)" with "section 1(d)" and making other specified amendments. SEC. 102 eliminates the marriage penalty in the standard deduction for taxable years starting after December 31, 2000. The standard deduction for different filing statuses is adjusted as follows: twice the dollar amount for joint returns and surviving spouses, $6,650 for heads of households, and $4,550 for others. Adjustments for inflation are made for taxable years after 2001. For taxable years beginning after 2001, dollar amounts in certain sections are increased based on the cost-of-living adjustment. This includes increasing the standard deduction amounts for different filing statuses. The amendments made by this section, including adjustments to dollar amounts in certain sections for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. SEC. 201. INDIVIDUAL INCOME TAX RATE REDUCTIONS. Amended tax rates for married individuals filing joint returns and surviving spouses. Individual income tax rates are determined based on taxable income brackets. For example, if taxable income is not over $12,600, the tax rate is 10% of taxable income. If taxable income is over $12,600 but not over $54,100, the tax rate is $1,260 plus 15% of the excess over $12,600. For taxable income over $54,100 but not over $273,500, the tax rate is $7,485 plus 25% of the excess over $54,100. For taxable income over $273,500, the tax rate is $62,335 plus 33% of the excess over $273,500. Heads of households have a separate tax table for their taxable income. "If taxable income is not over $10,800, the tax is 10% of taxable income. For income over $10,800 but not over $43,280, the tax is $1,080 plus 15% of the excess. Income over $43,280 but not over $218,800 incurs a tax of $5,952 plus 25% of the excess. For income over $218,800, the tax is $49,832 plus 33% of the excess. Other individuals are subject to a tax based on a separate table." "If taxable income is not over $6,300, the tax is 10% of taxable income. For income over $6,300 but not over $27,050, the tax is $630 plus 15% of the excess. Income over $27,050 but not over $136,750 incurs a tax of $3,742.50 plus 25% of the excess. For income over $136,750, the tax is $31,167.50 plus 33% of the excess. Estates and Trusts have a separate tax table for taxable income." "If taxable income is not over $1,800, the tax is 15% of taxable income. For income over $1,800 but not over $6,500, the tax is $270 plus 25% of the excess. Income over $6,500 incurs a tax of $1,445 plus 33% of the excess. Phasein of 2005 Rates applies for taxable years between 2000 and 2005." The Tax Relief and Marriage Penalty Elimination Act of 2001 reduced aggregate tax by 40%, 60%, and 80% for taxable years beginning in 2001, 2002, 2003, and 2004 respectively. The Secretary will adjust tables to implement these reductions. Technical amendments were made to various sections of the tax code, including reducing the tax rate from 39.6 percent to 33 percent in sections 531 and 541. Additionally, section 1 was amended to change the tax rate from 28 percent to 15 percent in certain paragraphs. The tax code was amended to reduce tax rates in various sections, such as changing rates from 39.6% to 33%, 28% to 15%, and 31% to 25% in different paragraphs. The Secretary of the Treasury has the authority to adjust these percentages as needed. The amendments made by this section of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2000, with specific withholding provisions applying to amounts paid after the enactment of the Act.
